task_list.description_text:
Simple (one tailed) if

The if command allows us to make a choice or a selection

In its simplest form, when the condition is met,
the program executes extra statements

The format of a one tailed if is:
if condition:
     statement

Example

if grade >= 90:
     print("Great work!")

Notes

Condition is anything that evaluates to a Boolean.
  • The condition can be simple or complex.
  • The condition must be followed by a colon

Task:

Display "Addition baggage charge"
if baggage weight is greater than 50 pounds

Test

weight output
50.1 Addition baggage charge

def match_secret_word(word):
    secret_word = "secret"

    condition for guess right
        result = "We have a winner"
    otherwise
        result = "Please try again"

    return result


word = input("Please guess the secret word: ")
print(match_secret_word(word))

tests/test_task.py.name: tests/test_task.py

task_list.description_text:
if - else (two tailed if)

If you have a choice, and you want to execute a certain set of statements if the condition is true, and another set of statements in the condition is false, you want to use if - else, the two tailed if

The format of a two tailed if is:

if condition:
     true statement(s)
else:
     false statement(s)

True statement(s) are executed if condition is true
False statement(s) are executed if condition is true

Note the colon after the condition and the else

Example

free_shipping_minimum = 25

if invoice_total >= free_shipping_minimum:
     print("Free shipping")
else:
     print("Pay for shipping")

Task:

Display ""We have a winner" if the user guesses the secret word
and "Please try again" if not

Tests

word output
secret We have a winner
a Please try again

task_list.name: Multi tailed if

task.py.name: task.py

placeholders.placeholder_text: condition for first line of commission table
condition for first line of commission table
condition for third line of commission table

task.py.text:
# author


def calculate_commission(sales):
    commission_percent = 0

    condition for first line of commission table
        commission_percent = 10
    condition for first line of commission table
        commission_percent = 7
    condition for third line of commission table
        commission_percent = 5

    return round(sales * commission_percent / 100, 2)


sales_amount = float(input("Please enter sales amount: "))
print("Commission is", '${:,.2f}'.format(calculate_commission(sales_amount)))

tests/test_task.py.name: tests/test_task.py

task_list.description_text:
if - elif - else (multi tailed if)

Often you have several levels of selection, not just two.
A grading scheme, for example, presents 5 outcomes: grades of A, B, C, D and F

While you could handle this with just if and else, the code is complex. It's much simpler to use the
if - elif - else construct.

Example

grade_percent_A = 90
grade_percent_B = 80
grade_percent_C = 70
grade_percent_D = 60

if gradePercent >= grade_percent_A:
     grade = "A"
elif gradePercent >= grade_percent_B:
     grade = "B"
elif gradePercent >= grade_percent_C:
     grade = "C"
elif gradePercent >= grade_percent_D:
     grade = "D"
else:
     grade = "F"

Note that elif assumes the if (or elif) preceding it is false, simplifying coding

For example, you don't have to code:
     elif gradePercent >= 80 and gradePercent < 90:
since the if preceding if gradePercent >= 90 is false.

Instead you code the simpler
     elif gradePercent >= 80:

Note: This is not a suggestion. This is good programming practice.
Maintenance is much easier if you don't have to change two values when the range changes

Task:

A company has the following commission structure:

Sales Commission Percent
>= 20000 10%
< 20000 and >= 10000 7%
< 10000 5%

Calculate the commission given sales.

Tests

Sales Commission Amount
20000 $2,000.00
19999.99 $1,400.00
10000 $700.00
9999.99 $500.00

task_list.name: Lists

task.py.name: task.py

placeholders.placeholder_text: return item at specified index from my_list

task.py.text:
# author


def add_to_list(my_list, item):
    Add item to my_list
    return my_list


def select_from_list(my_list, index):
    return item at specified index from my_list


groceries = ["bread", "milk", "sugar"]
print("First item in grocery list", select_from_list(groceries, 0))
print("Last item in grocery list", select_from_list(groceries, len(groceries) - 1))
print()

item_to_add = input("What item do you want to add to the grocery list? ")
add_to_list(groceries, item_to_add)

print("First item in grocery list", select_from_list(groceries, 0))
print("Last item in grocery list", select_from_list(groceries, len(groceries) - 1))

tests/test_task.py.name: tests/test_task.py

task_list.description_text:
Lists

A list is a data structure that allows you to group items together

A list is contained within square brackets [ ]
and the values are separated by commas

Values in the list can be of the same or different types, although normally lists containing values of the same type are easier to work with

You can add an item to the list using
list += [item]
You can access an individual item of a list by using:
list[index]
where index is a number for 0 to the length of the list minus one

Example:

groceries = ["bread", "milk", "sugar"]
groceries += ["eggs"]

the list now has 4 items:

  • groceries[0] = "bread"
  • groceries[1] = "milk"
  • groceries[2] = "sugar"
  • groceries[3] = "eggs"

Task

Write a function to add an item to a list.
Write a function to select an item from a list

task_list.description_text:
split Method

split is a method that breaks down a string by a separator
returns a list of words

Example:

groceries = "bread,milk,sugar"
groceries_list = groceries.split(",")

groceries_list will now be a list of ["bread", "milk", "sugar"]

into European format (dd/mm/yyyy)

task_list.description_text:
For Loop

For loops are used when you want to execute a block of code a fixed number of times,
where the program, if not the programmer, knows how many times the block of code should be executed.

Example:

Display all the colors in a list

colors = ["red", "green", "orange"]
for color in colors:
     print(color)

This code iterates through the colors list using the color variable

First, color takes the value of element 0 ("red"); it prints "red"
Then, color takes the value of element 1 ("green"); it prints "gren"
Finally, color takes the value of element 2 ("orange"); it prints "orange"

Having run out of colors, the loop stops

Task

Print all elements of the groceries list

task_list.name: while loops

task.py.name: task.py

tests/test_task.py.name: tests/test_task.py

task_list.description_text:
while Loop

A while loop executes code statements as long as a condition is true.

Its format is:

while condition:
     statements
where condition evaluates to True or False

Note:

For the statements to execute, condition must originally be True
If the condition never becomes false, we have an infinite loop

Task

Just look at the code to see how it works
The homework assignment has a problem that needs code like this
No coding necessary

Always validates using Check

task_list.name: while loop exercise

main.py.name: main.py
main.py.text:
# author
def enter_user_name():
    is_continue = True

    while loop control
        my_name = input("Please enter your name: ")
        condition for exit
            is_continue = False
        else:
            print("Please enter name whose length is between 3 and 20 characters")

    return my_name


name = enter_user_name()
print("Hi,", name)

tests/output.txt.name: tests/output.txt
tests/output.txt.text:
Please enter your name: Please enter name whose length is between 3 and 20 characters
Please enter your name: Please enter name whose length is between 3 and 20 characters
Please enter your name: Please enter name whose length is between 3 and 20 characters
Please enter your name: Hi, Ace
